entry.title: A Trick for LaTeX
entry.content:
After using LaTeX to do homework for a semester, I created many shortcuts that make it much easier for me to type complicated formula. Here I share one of my tricks which can be easily generalized.

Environments enclosed in \begin and \end are often annoying to type. We can define a macro to simplify it. For example, I frequently use the environment “equation*”. We can define a macro

latex \newcommand{\seq}[1]{\begin{eqnarray*}#1\end{eqnarray*}}

Then we can type a formula by

latex \seqnarray{ |x_n - x_m| &=& |x_{m+k} - x_{m}| = |x_{m+k} - x_{m+k-1} + x_{m+k-1} - x_{m+k-2} + \cdots + x_{m+1} - x_m| \\ &\leq& |x_{m+k} - x_{m+k-1}| + |x_{m+k-1} - x_{m+k-2}| + \cdots + |x_{m+1} - x_m| \\ &\leq& |x_2 - x_1| (C^{m+k-2} + C^{m+k-3} + \cdots + C^{m-1}) \\ &=& |x_2 - x_1| C^{m-1} (C^{k-1} + C^{k-2} + \cdots + 1) \\ &=& |x_2 - x_1| C^{m-1} \frac{1 - C^k}{1 - C} < \frac{|x_2 - x_1|C^{M-1}}{1 - C} }

The same trick can be applied to all other environments to obtain a C-style command.
